utterances: Here is now a pretty stern discussion.
We have not only members of government and the international organizations, we have also civil society.
And the tone of these discussions is very open and very frank.
We have interactive discussions, and we are hearing that they are improving the rate of success on certain sectors.
So it's moving ahead in some areas, it's going backwards in others.
Let's get some callers in on the conversation, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
What should the world leaders get done this week here in New York?
We'll go to Scott(ph), Scott with us from Greenville, South Carolina.
Gentlemen, good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
The topic I would propose would be piracy - internationally, around the world.
It's expensive, lives are risked and it destabilizes the governments in areas where it takes place, especially Somalia.
And it's an important issue.
Jan Eliasson, would you expect that anything could get accomplished at a meeting like the U.N.
General Debate on such an issue?
This piracy situation is an example of how difficult it is to divorce ourselves from what goes on in the rest of the world.
Somalia is called a so-called failed state.
But in this failed state, so-called failed state, is the best organized piracy operation in the world, which affects the shipping and insurance rates.
This is a problem that has been dealt with both by law-and-order actions, and you have navy units from all over the world, practically, to deal with this.

But I also want to point at something that I heard from my friends from Africa, and that is that there's been tremendous amount of fishing in that area so that in the villages, there's no economic basis to carry on fishing, and young people are taking to this illegal action, of course.
And then secondly, there were also lots of chemical waste thrown at the borders, at the beaches of Somalia when this complete disruption took place during the civil war.
So this matter comes up indirectly.
It's a failed state, but it's also proof that we have to realize that we are together in this world.
One of the difficulties in pursuing piracy has been the lack of a agreed legal system to attack it.
Is the United Nations an appropriate institution to say we need to revise our laws on piracy, international crime?
I think so.
This is a typical example of today's problems that is not fully dealt with.
And I think there are discussions going on, how we should deal with the piracy operations.
I'm not really informed about the details, but it's going on.
All right, Scott, thanks very much for the phone call, appreciate it.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can go next to - this is Troy(ph), Troy with us from Iowa City.
After the emotion, the spending, the euphoria and, in some cases, the devastation of the last election, Congress is back at work this week.
That includes the lawmakers who were defeated.
Yes, I would like them to address the fraud that is being done with billions of dollars that the U.N.
has just - unfortunately can't account for.
And why should the United States citizen pay the U.N.
money when the U.N.
ambassadors can't even pay their parking tickets to New York?
Well, fraud is - we've had the example of the U.N.
Food for Fuel Program in Iraq that was found to be, and I think other people complained about the amount of bureaucracy at the United Nations.
And Ambassador Eliasson, do you think that this is something that can be dealt with at this meeting?
It's something that the United States, still the largest donor to the United Nations, the citizenry complains about a great deal.
Well, I understand this concern, and of course, the organization is definitely not perfect.
I have served this organization also myself and have seen the bureaucracy.
But I think if you look at the larger perspective, there is so much of value that is done by this organization.

I was responsible for emergency operations all over the world back in the '90s, and I can tell you that people are working day and night and to the sacrifice of their lives to help people who are struck by civil wars or by natural disasters.
But I think it's important that also one of the greatest countries of the world realizes that it is important to find ways to cooperate together with other nations.
Going it alone is not the right way to go.
And we will have difficulty working up a good cooperation among all nations, but it's the only one we have.
And the United Nations is not the organization that reflects the world that we would like to see.
It's the reflection of the world as it is.
But I'm glad to see the new signs of interest from the American administration to deal with the United Nations as a partner.
And when you've been here in New York, based in New York at various times, did you pay your parking tickets?
I did.
Sweden always paid their tickets.
So we rarely had parking tickets.
I think, at least from my perspective, is an exaggerated issue.

We should try to see the positive values of having the world organization in the United States to show that there has to be cooperation among even the greatest and most powerful nations and the rest of the world, the 191 other countries.
Shakespeare used to say, said once that there's a world outside Verona.
And I think we all have to realize that there is a world outside Verona.
And in today's world, you can't simply take that away.
It's a fact of life, whether we like it or not.
Stuart's(ph) on the line from Baltimore.
Yes, good afternoon.
Great program, gentlemen.

Do you think the United Nations could do a better job in communicating the fine work that it really does and communicate it in a way that the general public will appreciate the enormous amount of money that is spent but obviously the great work that is accomplished?
I was thinking of that when I was in the camps of Darfur.
You know, two million people sitting in camps, population of six million, and I saw my colleagues from the U.N.
working day and night.
And some of them were American, and I said to them: Why don't you go home and tell the story?
It seems like they didn't want to brag.
But there is so much going out there.
While we are talking, kids are being vaccinated.
Medicine is being distributed.
Wells are being drilled.
Lots of things are being done which are not known.
So I really appreciate your question.
It comes as a great relief to hear that type of question, and I wish we could see more of that.
But we'd certainly have to improve this relation.
I'm the first one to say that.
I was negotiating reforms, and it was a very heavy exercise.
Stuart...
Keep up the good work, please.
I just wanted to ask you, Stuart, when you bring up this point at parties or at dinner with other people in Baltimore, how do they respond?
I think there's a serious lack of awareness of the depth and breadth of what it is being done, and often politics held visions of really the work that's done.
I think the U.N.
could do a much better job in connecting with grassroots support across the world, actually.
But, anyway, that would be my plea.
Okay.
I would say that this is very interesting, and I would say something that might sound paradoxical.
Maybe we have too high expectations on the U.N.
We point at the U.N.
up there in the air and expect the U.N.
to solve all problems.
But that is not going to be the case.
We need, in this world, to have a sense of international division of labor.
Governments have a responsibility.
The academic world has a responsibility.
The NGO community has a responsibility.
Nobody can do everything, but everybody can do something.
These global problems are so huge that we simply have to take our part of the problem.
And in that discussion, U.N.
has one part, but all of us have other parts.
And of course, in communicating that message, the U.N.
would have to be careful not to be seen to be propagandizing anybody, so...
Exactly.
...that's the other side of the line.
Stuart, thanks very much for the call.
It's a pleasure.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Email from Joni(ph) in Saint Louis.
I truly believe the main and first topic that needs to be addressed is the speed with which global warming is affecting each one of the nations that are gathered.
Please have them tell me their country is doing great, and that there's no future danger for their citizens.
I do dare them.
What are the promises that have been made, and what difference does it all make if we can't survive in our climate?
So the environment, you're dealing with it specifically on the issue of clean water, but that is affected by changing climates as well?
NPR's Andrea Seabrook reports on freshmen orientation.
Let's get Rick(ph) on the line, Rick with us from Shingletown, California.
Yeah.
I met the president of Maldives sometime ago.
His island will be disappearing from the map in about 100 years.
He's already making plans to move his population.
We will have an enormous movement of people from the rise of the sea level.
